ORG The applicant monasteries , which were founded between DATE , accumulated a considerable amount of property , in particular through donations made before the creation of ORG in DATE , but a large part of this property was expropriated during DATE of the ORG ’s existence . The monasteries themselves also gave away whole tracts of land to the ORG or to individuals who had none . During the NORP and NORP empires the monasteries and religious institutions in general were almost the only institutions discharging important social , cultural and educational functions ; even in DATE after the creation of the modern GPE , they still discharged some of these functions .

The ORG never challenged their ownership , and the monasteries always relied on adverse possession as a subsidiary means of establishing it , particularly in cases where NORP or NORP title deeds were lacking or had been destroyed . On several occasions the ORG published decrees in ORG in which their ownership was acknowledged ( decrees of DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , etc . ) .
CARDINAL . Apart from property thus amassed over DATE , the monasteries acquired numerous plots of land and buildings more recently , either as gifts or legacies or through purchase .

CARDINAL . ORG Under PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , their land and buildings were classified as either " property to be realised " ( ekpiitea perioussia ) or " property to be retained " ( diatiritea perioussia ) .

The second category included property considered necessary for the needs of a given monastery , having regard , inter alia , to the number of its members and to its historic value as a place of pilgrimage , and they were listed in a decree adopted on a proposal by the Minister for Education and ORG . CARDINAL . ORG The ties binding the NORP nation - and later the NORP State - to ORG go back DATE . The interdependence of ORG and ORG was already apparent in the administrative reorganisation of the ORG which followed the restructuring of ORG .

The ORG ’s historical role grew more important after the collapse of GPE . The ORG of GPE was recognised as millet basi - the spiritual leader , at the same time answerable to ORG , of the NORP community , which became integrated into the administrative machinery of GPE through the ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG was proclaimed to be " autocephalous " in a royal decree of DATE and was at the same time given its first LAW , which was very noticeably imbued with the spirit of ORG control ; the ORG was independent of the ORG only in matters of doctrine .

LAW of DATE , in its references to LAW of DATE and LAW of DATE , on the one hand , and to ORG Synod of serving metropolitans " ) as the ORG authority , on the other , evidences the intention of breaking with the old tradition of ORG control . The proclaimed independence of the ORG is not , however , unlimited , as is shown by the fact that ORG is the church of the " dominant religion " and embodies the religion of the ORG itself .
CARDINAL . The Law of CARDINAL DATE ( Law no . PERSON ) on LAW " also provides for interdependence of ORG and ORG .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) attributes to the ORG and a number of its institutions , including the monasteries , legal personality in public law " as regards their legal relations " .

Under LAW , the ORG is to co - operate with the ORG in fields of common interest , such as the NORP upbringing of young people , enhancing the status of the institution of marriage and of the family , caring for those in need of protection and safeguarding sacred relics and ecclesiastical monuments . The ORG ’s role in public life is reflected more markedly by the presence of the Minister for ORG and ORG at the sessions held to elect the Archbishop of GPE and by the participation of ORG authorities in all official ORG events .

The provisions on the ORG ’s finances and staffing testify even more eloquently to this interdependence . As to financing , the PERSON provides that the ORG is to contribute to the ORG ’s expenses ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , that the ORG ’s resources are to be managed in a manner determined by decision of ORG , approved by ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , and that managerial acts are subject to the ORG ’s financial supervision ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . As to staffing , the provisions governing public servants are to apply by analogy to the staff of ORG public - law entities .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the PERSON describes the Holy Monasteries as ascetic religious institutions whose members live according to monastic principles , the sacred rules of asceticism and the traditions of ORG . The Holy Monasteries come under the spiritual supervision of the local archbishop ( section CARDINAL ) ) . The organisation and furtherance of spiritual life within the monasteries and the running of them are the responsibility of the monastic councils and conform to the holy rules and monastic traditions ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

The Holy Monasteries are public - law entities ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . They may be founded , merged or dissolved by means of a presidential decree , adopted on a proposal by the Minister for Education and ORG after consultation of the local archbishop and with the approval of ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .

The decisions of the monastery councils are preparatory in nature , taking effect only after they have been ratified by the higher ORG authority . Judicial review lies only against the decisions of the latter authority .

ORG , the supreme Church authority , has power to regulate the internal organisation and administration of the ORG and the monasteries ; it scrutinises the decisions of ORG , of the archbishops and of the other ORG legal entities including the monasteries ( section CARDINAL ) and ( g ) ) , over which the ORG exercises no authority . The ecclesiastical legal persons which make up ORG , in the broad sense , constitute an entity distinct from the public service and enjoy complete autonomy .

DATE was published in ORG of CARDINAL DATE and changed the rules on the management and representation of monastery property within the charge of the ORG , most of whose members were now to be appointed by the ORG . The factors which prompted the ORG to enact new rules on ORG property are set out in the explanatory memorandum to the bill . The following passages should be noted :

" This bill deals with the question of the immovable property in the ORG ’s possession DATE , a question that since the beginning of the modern GPE has caused friction not only between ORG and ORG but also between the latter and ... the people ; under the present system , many national treasures remain unexploited ...

The ORG ’s current possessions are largely the remnants of a period in which the ORG ’s existence was dependent solely on its own property and even on its own labour . Since then , its operating conditions have radically changed . The ORG covers nearly all its needs . Concurrently with the provisions of this bill , provision is being made for the first time for subsidies from the ORG budget to ORG and the ORG in general , so that they may expand their spiritual mission , which is so necessary for the nation and for the NORP faith in GPE and abroad ...

A large part of this immovable property has been wasted in unlawful and disadvantageous transactions or usurped by skilful exploiters , while the rest has largely been abandoned or is being utilised detrimentally by third parties . This national heritage is continually shrinking and tending to disappear as a productive source of wealth for the country ’s agriculture , stockbreeding and forestry .

Furthermore , most of the lands now in the ORG ’s possession belong to the ORG . They are occupied without legal title and with the ORG ’s toleration . This national property is constantly being diminished by illegal sales and encroachments which lead to usurpations of land and uncontrolled development ; this is a situation which undermines the ORG ’s authority .

It should be remembered that since DATE the ORG has legislated to make the transfer of CARDINAL of the monasteries’ property to the ORG compulsory , for the benefit of those who do not have any land ( Decree no . DATE ) . This statutory obligation has not hitherto been enforced . "

CARDINAL . ORG gave its ruling on DATE ( judgment no . DATE ) , stating :

The provisions of LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW safeguard the holy canons and traditions of ORG . However , this constitutional protection ... can not be regarded as extending to the canons and traditions relating to purely administrative matters . Such matters , which are affected by the passing of time and the advent of new ideas , necessarily lend themselves to changes designed to promote the common interests of ORG and ORG . The ordinary legislature regulates them according to society ’s needs , in accordance with LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW . It can not , however , ... by means of the ORG ’s LAW or other statutory provisions , undertake a radical reform of the basic administrative institutions , which have long been solidly established in ORG ... Furthermore , the same provisions also guarantee the ORG ’s autonomy , which includes the power to determine its own affairs through its own organs composed as provided for by law and to be governed by ORG constituted in accordance with the law and the provisions of LAW of DATE and LAW of DATE concerning the composition of these bodies .

In the view of the majority of this ORG , the provisions of PERSON no . DATE , which vests the management and representation of the Holy Monasteries’ property in the ORG , a public - law entity integrated into the administrative framework of the ORG and a majority of whose board of governors’ members are appointed by the ORG , are not incompatible with the ORG ’s autonomy - guaranteed by the LAW - or with freedom of religion or with LAW and CARDINAL of LAW ... or with LAW ... or with LAW of GPE ... , as these matters , unconnected with doctrine or worship , are purely administrative and unrelated to the ORG ’s basic administrative institutions ; consequently , they must be freely regulated by the ordinary legislature ... Furthermore , the provisions of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL do not materially affect those institutions as the management of monastery and ORG had always been vested in the ORG , whose board of governors - as constituted under PERSON no . CARDINAL - was composed , for the greater part , of lay members appointed by the ORG ... The grounds of nullity are accordingly ill - founded and must be rejected .

However , CARDINAL of the senior members of the ORG has expressed the following opinion , in which he is joined by CARDINAL of the junior members ( paredri ) . LAW , which provides that ORG is to be governed by ‘ the ORG of serving ORG safeguards not only the ORG ’s autonomy in the sense that it is governed by metropolitans elected by it but also the right to manage and dispose of , at its discretion ... , the movable and immovable property of every kind belonging to it in order to achieve its non - profit - making aims , namely the establishment and promotion of the NORP faith of its members . Monastic life in monastic communities , which are vital parts of that ORG ... and which , despite their status as public - law entities , derive , like the ORG itself , from an area lying outside the jurisdiction of the ORG , has always constituted a fundamental mode of the worship of God . To deprive all the monasteries of the management and representation of all their existing and future ... property and to assign those powers to the ODEP without their consent ... is consequently an unacceptable restriction of their autonomy and of that of the ORG ... These provisions entail , in the first place , a breach of the aforementioned LAW , which does not allow the ORG ’s administrative institutions to be altered to the point of removing its autonomy , and , secondly , seriously hamper the practice of worship through monastic life , since they prevent the ‘ unrestricted’ practice of monastic worship , as secured in LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW . Lastly , it must be pointed out that from DATE the ORG was run by a board of governors a majority of whose members were appointed by ORG and which was chaired by ORG of GPE ... ; the precedents to the contrary cited by the majority relate to isolated special cases and not to the monasteries’ property as a whole . The minority consequently consider the grounds of nullity to be well - founded .

The applicants also maintained that the provisions of Law no . DATE , which vested the management and representation of the monasteries’ property in the ODEP - an entity separate from the ORG and not controlled by it - and authorised the transfer of that property to the ORG without any compensation , were contrary to LAW and CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( a ) of the LAW as they made mandatory provision for an unacceptable transfer of that property , deprived the Holy Monasteries of their ownership and introduced unconstitutional restrictions on property rights .

Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( a ) of the LAW prohibits any general confiscation . LAW provides that ownership is under the protection of the ORG but that rights deriving from it can not be exercised to the detriment of the public interest ... No one may be deprived of his property unless in the public interest , duly made out , in the eventualities and according to the procedure laid down by law and in every case subject to full prior compensation ... This latter provision of the LAW prohibits any deprivation of property that does not satisfy the foregoing conditions ; nothing , however , prevents the legislature from restricting the right of ownership on the basis of objective criteria and in the public interest , on condition that such restrictions do not nullify the right and make it ineffective ...

In the view of the majority of the ORG , the provisions of PERSON no . DATE , ... which provide for the transfer to ORG of the ownership of the monasteries’ agricultural land and of other immovable property owned by LOC without any title deed , are not contrary to LAW as they do not deprive the Holy Monasteries of their ownership ( idioktissia ) ; the PERSON in fact means that this immovable property does not belong to them . Moreover , the provisions of the PERSON concerning the sale of the Holy Monasteries’ urban immovable property or the granting of rights in rem relating to it by decision of the ODEP ... do not infringe the Holy Monasteries’ right of ownership inasmuch as their implementation is subject to the agreement of ORG which owns the immovable property , failing which the contract is void . Lastly , the provisions relating to the ... utilisation by the ODEP of urban immovable property and mines , quarries and fish farms belonging to the Holy Monasteries or any other ORG institution and those relating to the management and representation of ... agricultural property ... and the present or future utilisation of urban immovable property do not entail any deprivation of ownership since the ownership as such remains in the hands of the Holy Monasteries , and in any case the revenue from the ORG ’s management of this property is used for ecclesiastical purposes ... ; the provisions lay down constitutional restrictions on ownership which are designed to serve at one and the same time the monasteries’ interest and the public interest . In consequence , this ground of nullity , together with the complaints relating to LAW paras . CARDINAL and DATE and LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW and LAW ( PCARDINAL - CARDINAL ) ... , are ill - founded and must be rejected ...

CARDINAL senior members of the ORG , joined by CARDINAL of the junior members , have expressed the following opinion . Transferring the management and representation of the whole of the monasteries’ property to the ODEP on the aforementioned terms , even ‘ as an amendment to the legal provisions in force’ ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . DATE ) , does not amount to a restriction of ownership , which is allowed by LAW , but interferes unacceptably and without full compensation with the very essence of the right of ownership . This is all the more evident as the only possibility left open to the monasteries is either to consent or to object to the sale of their urban property or the granting of a right in rem relating to it by the ODEP , without being able to decide the matter for themselves : such a decision belongs exclusively to the ORG , which has unfettered discretion to determine , without even consulting the monasteries , the sale of agricultural land and ‘ the present and future utilisation’ of their immovable property such as is provided for in section CARDINAL of PERSON no . DATE . As to the monasteries’ movable property , some of which is extremely valuable ( icons in monastery museums , precious relics , shares , etc . ) , they are managed by the ODEP without any restrictions whatever . Furthermore , it should be noted that PERSON no . DATE does not specify how the income from monastic property is to be applied ; on the other hand , it appears from sections ORG ) , ORG ) and CARDINAL of Law no . DATE that the ORG ’s revenue from the ‘ utilisation or granting of the use of monastic and Church property’ is to be transferred to a private - law entity set up under LAW which does not have any ecclesiastical objectives . The provisions of PERSON no . As to the submission that the provisions of LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL infringe LAW para . Moreover , it is alleged that the provisions of Law no . DATE infringe LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW in that NORP citizens who wish to support the monasteries financially are impeded in their self - fulfilment since , contrary to their wishes , the management of donations would vest not in the monasteries but in the ORG .

Furthermore , it is submitted that these provisions infringe the individual freedom of religion of the members of monastic communities and of those who would like to found a monastery by dedicating their assets to that end . The first limb of the ground is ill - founded since the individual right of free self - fulfilment , secured in DATE . CARDINAL of the LAW , is not an absolute right ; it is subject to the restrictions laid down in the LAW and in law . In the instant case the restrictions deriving from the aforementioned provisions of LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ... do not infringe LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW . The ground is also ill - founded in its second limb , since it refers vaguely to possible damage sustained by the applicants in the future .

ORG nevertheless quashed the Minister for Education and Religious Affairs’ decision of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , on the ground that the composition of the ORG ’s governing body did not satisfy the requirements of LAW no . DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The passing of PERSON no . DATE had produced a sharp reaction from ORG . With a view to calming the situation , the ORG and ORG held a series of meetings and concluded a preliminary accord under which the monasteries would , by means of a further agreement , transfer part of their property to the ORG . An essential condition of the preliminary accord was that ORG would have to seek from each monastery council full powers to sign the further agreement .

CARDINAL . ORG On CARDINAL DATE the Standing Holy Synod duly concluded a further agreement with the ORG , whereby CARDINAL monasteries , including the applicant monasteries of PERSON , ORG and Phlamourion Volou , transferred their agricultural and forest property to the ORG ; CARDINAL monasteries declared that they were not affected by the agreement since they did not have any substantial property of that kind . ORG ratified the agreement in LAW no . DATE , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of which provided : " On publication of this PERSON , the management of the urban property of LOC that are not parties to the agreement shall revert to ORG of ORG . The provisions of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL shall apply to the remainder of these monasteries’ property . "

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided that monasteries which were not parties to the agreement could join it within a renewable period of DATE from the commencement of the PERSON ; the operation of PERSON no . DATE was not , however , suspended during that period .

CARDINAL . ORG Under clause CARDINAL of the agreement , the monasteries parties to it are to cede to the ORG all their agricultural and forest property except for the land surrounding them within a radius of QUANTITY ; a monastery ’s opinion must be sought before any leisure facilities , restaurants or business are established in its vicinity and operated . Furthermore , the monasteries are authorised to retain a proportion of their original real property - provided that the total area of land retained does not exceed QUANTITY . m of forest or QUANTITY . m of agricultural land - and PERCENT of land " usable for tourism purposes " ; ORG is allotted PERCENT of land included in the town development plan after DATE . Lastly , land in the monasteries’ possession by virtue of a title deed or which has passed to them under a will or a deed of gift is exempt from transfer .
A special committee set up in each prefecture by a decision of the ORG is to determine which land is to be transferred to the ORG and which is to be kept by each monastery .

In exchange for the transfer of ownership , the ORG undertakes to pay a stipend to CARDINAL preachers and to spend PERCENT of the budgetary appropriations earmarked for the ORG on financially supporting the monasteries that are parties to the agreement ( clause CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under clause CARDINAL of the agreement , the ORG was destined to be wound up once the operations had been concluded ; in fact the ODEP was dissolved after ORG ’s ratification of the agreement and the members of its staff were assigned to other ORG bodies in accordance with section CARDINAL of Law no . DATE . The management of the urban property and part of the agricultural and forest property remaining in the ownership of the monasteries parties to the agreement is to be their responsibility , while ORG , having taken over the rights and obligations of the ORG and having exclusive authority to act , is to be responsible for the property to be realised . ORG is to lay down in canonical decisions published in ORG the manner in which ORG transferred to ORG on the abolition of the ORG is to be managed and utilised . Lastly , the monasteries parties to the agreement have capacity to take legal proceedings in any dispute relating to the property they retain under it ( clause CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Some of the monasteries - including Phlamourion Volou - which had authorised ORG to negotiate and sign the agreement with the ORG applied to the courts , alleging that the agreement was null and void .

They argued , inter alia , that ( CARDINAL ) the agreement had been concluded by ORG , a purely administrative body of ORG with no legal personality of its own or any legal capacity ; ( CARDINAL ) the archbishops and metropolitans who had taken part in the drawing up of the agreement were not the Standing Holy Synod ’s statutory representatives ; ( CARDINAL ) the tracts of land which the monasteries had undertaken to transfer were not precisely delimited and the agreement made no mention of their location , area or boundaries ; ( CARDINAL ) ORG had not acted through its statutory representative ; ( CARDINAL ) at the time that the agreement was concluded , the ORG was responsible for the management and representation of the monasteries’ property and ownership of that property had already been transferred to the ORG under LAW no . CARDINAL ; ( CARDINAL ) the authorisations issued by the monasteries to ORG had not been in the form of notarial documents as required by law ; and ( CARDINAL ) the conditions that were stipulated by the monasteries for concluding the agreement and which appeared in the authorisations to act were not reproduced in the actual text of the agreement .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG gave judgment against the monastery of FAC .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG dismissed an appeal by the monastery against that judgment . It noted , in particular , like the court below but in more detail , that by LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL the legislature had expressed the intention of ratifying the agreement in its entirety even if it contained formal or substantive defects which might have rendered it null and void under enactments in force at the time it was concluded .

Complaint no . CARDINAL was rejected by ORG on the ground that the monastery of ORG had no locus standi , since at the time the agreement was concluded it had ceased to be the owner of the land in question . As for complaints FAC . CARDINAL and DATE , the court held that because of the large number of monasteries involved , the agreement could only distinguish in a general way between the land to be transferred and the land to be retained and it assigned the task of laying down the precise boundaries to a committee to be set up in each prefecture .

Furthermore , the wording of clause CARDINAL of the agreement did not suffice on its own to show that the full powers granted to ORG had been exceeded or that there had been any misuse of powers on the part of the archbishops who had signed the agreement ; if that had been the case and if land not covered by the authority to act had been transferred to the ORG , it would have amounted to a deprivation of property incompatible with LAW , a defect that could not have been cured by the ratification . It was , however , impossible to determine whether the full powers had been exceeded as the appellant had not stated whether the relevant committee had already carried out its task .

Lastly , the disputed agreement was an agreement for value , as the ORG undertook to support the monasteries that were parties to it by transferring to them PERCENT of the budgetary appropriations earmarked for the ORG and to meet the cost of remunerating CARDINAL preachers .
